comments:
I accidentally destroyed one of my projects (and spent a good deal of
time understanding what had happened) by using "new source folder".  I
naively believed that this was the way to add a new subtree of sources
to the project.  In fact, I know now, "new folder" is the way.

I'm not sure under what scenario the "new source folder" option is intended
to be useful, but it is clear that the way I was allowed to use it is
completely inappropriate.   Either the option should not have been available,
or trying to use it should have evoked dire warnings of the consequences.
Ie: "Warning, this will make 236 current source files NO LONGER BE CONSISIDERED
 TO BE SOURCE FILES" for this project."

What "new source folder" did was to throw away my existing source folder,
which effectively made all of my EXISTING sources no longer part of the
project.  Not realizing what had actually happened, I continued trying
to edit and debug the project, greatly mystified because none of the
class files were found when I tried to debug.

   load: class online.Root.class not found.
   java.lang.ClassNotFoundException: online.Root.class
	at sun.applet.AppletClassLoader.findClass(Unknown Source)


Whereas previously the project had been running fine.

BEFORE the change, my .classpath looked like this:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<classpath>
	<classpathentry kind="src" path=""/>
	<classpathentry kind="con" path="org.eclipse.jdt.launching.JRE_CONTAINER"/>
	<classpathentry kind="output" path="bin"/>
</classpath>

AFTER using "new source folder" my .classpath looked like this:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<classpath>
	<classpathentry kind="src" path="test"/>
	<classpathentry kind="con" path="org.eclipse.jdt.launching.JRE_CONTAINER"/>
	<classpathentry kind="output" path="bin"/>
</classpath>

Instead of showing a message dialog we could automatically move the packages
from the implicit source folder of the project to the newly created source
folder or exclude the new source folder from the default source folder.

if that were the behavior, the name of the menu item should
be changed to "move sources to new folder".  Presumably
you would have to refactor all the existing sources too.

The worst aspect of the current behavior is that it turns
a working project into a nonworking one.  Anything that made
that less likely would be an improvement, but what is the
answer to the implied question "what is new source folder"
inteded to be used for?   In its present form, I can't
think of any legitimate use in a working project.

There is lots of opportunity for confusion about packages and
classpaths while initially constructing a project.  I think
operations in support of resolving that confusion deserve
a separate wizard, not items in the general menu of choices.

This should be more clean in 3.2: The radio buttons on the dialog lets you choose to either replace the cufrrent project as source folder or keep it and add exclusion rules.

Reopen if you still find this unclear.
